before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"6amk9","text":"Prepare stock solutions/reagents as described in the section Preparation of Stock Solutions (Steps 1-3), and Preparation of Oligonucleotide Solutions (Steps 4-6). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"394fc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a2po6","text":"The assumed input to the protocol is a sample processed by by a Targeted ExSeq Tissue Preparation, as described in Step 7.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"4ntvv","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"49e9v","text":"This protocol accompanies Expansion Sequencing (ExSeq), describing the process of targeted ExSeq library preparation for a sample that has been processed according to a Targeted ExSeq Tissue Preparation protocol. The steps described here are a generalization of the protocol used in figures 4-6 of the paper, and represent our recommendations for future users of the technology. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":26,"length":20}],"data":{}},{"key":"93fei","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"11hjp","text":"The flowchart in Fig. 1A depicts the library preparation workflow. Fig. 1B is a summary of the product, in which padlock probes are amplified to form amplicon concatamers. The net result of the process is that barcode sequences are delivered to transcripts of interest and locally amplified hundreds to thousands of times. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":17,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":67,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eb9iq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a7vea","text":"The process of library preparation encompasses the following steps. (1) Oligonucleotide padlock probes bearing barcode sequences hybridize to RNA transcripts of interest (Step 8). (2) SplintR Ligase, which can has RNA-splinted DNA ligase activity, ligates adjacent ends of padlock probes, forming circular DNA molecules (Step 9). (3) A universal primer hybridizes to all padlock probes (Step 10). (4) Rolling Circle Amplification initiates from the primers, and repeatedly copies the sequence of the padlock probes, forming an amplicon (Step 11). (5) BS(PEG)9 covalently cross-links the amplicon to itself, stabilizing the amplicon (Steps 12-13) during in situ sequencing. At this point, the sample is now ready for downstream detection (i.e. via hybridizing fluorophore-labeled oligos to the amplicon (Step 14), and in situ sequencing).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":653,"length":7},{"style":"italic","offset":817,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"491s8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9m01m","text":"This protocol was used (with no modifications) to profile human metastatic breast cancer biopsies as a part of the Human Tumor Atlas Pilot Project (HTAPP).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"1899AA80A79D11EB99B27BF1F60ABCE0","height":229,"id":188844,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":8,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":3,"offset":10,"style":"bold"},{"length":3,"offset":59,"style":"bold"}],"key":"frt4c","text":"Figure 1. (A) Summary of steps described in this protocol. (B) Sequence-level description of library preparation.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Targeted_ExSeq_Brain_Library_Preparation_Flowchart_v0.3.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2pq9yv6.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2pn9yv6.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2pp9yv6.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2pm9yv6.webp","width":550}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"1832ED8DBB7811EABC4E0A58A9FEAC2A","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33509999/"}}}}

guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"autfl","text":"This protocol has some overlap with the hybridization steps of Expansion FISH (Chen*, Wassie*, et al. (2016)), detailed in more depth in a published Expansion FISH protocol (along with other expansion microscopy protocols) with detailed debugging advice  (Asano*, Gao*, Wassie* et al. (2018)). Prospective users are encouraged to review that protocol as well, as it overlaps partly with steps 8, 10, and 14.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":79,"length":29},{"key":1,"offset":256,"length":35}],"data":{}},{"key":"a441r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a467r","text":"A typical gel can fit in a PCR tube or a microcentrifuge tube. The explicit volumes listed in the proocol are for 200 μL, sufficient to fill a PCR tube, and easy to scale up to 300-600 μL, typically enough for samples in microcentrifuge tubes. We note that the volumes can be decreased, as long as the gel is completely submerged. For small gels, 50-100 μL in PCR tubes is sufficient for the hybridization, ligation, and rolling circle amplification steps, which can help save on the cost of reagents.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"13eq0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"efvo9","text":"For washes, the volume should be significantly larger than the volume of the gel. Our suggested volumes are 200 μL for PCR tubes, and 500-1000 μL for microcentrifuge tubes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eqihq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"66co5","text":"Four temperatures are used in this protocol:  ,  ,  ,  . We recommend the use of  dedicated, RNAse-free incubators/fridges (i.e., not used for any bacterial or yeast work) with pre-heated/cooled metal tube racks (often called \"cold blocks\"), or a thermocycler for temperature control.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":45,"length":1},{"key":3,"offset":48,"length":1},{"key":4,"offset":51,"length":1},{"key":5,"offset":54,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7tu3n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e3jaf","text":"All reagents used should be RNAse-free. We have provided specific product numbers in the materials section. Of particular note, \"water\" always refers to UltraPure Water (nuclease-free).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ajtr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1tqm7","text":"If additional SplintR Ligase Buffer is needed, note that 10X T4 DNA Ligase Buffer (NEB B0202S) is identical to 10X SplintR Ligase Buffer.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"D538AD72BFC311EA85EB0A58A9FEAC2A","url":"https://www.nature.com/articles/nmeth.3899"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"E700118CBFC311EA85EB0A58A9FEAC2A","url":"http://syntheticneurobiology.org/publications/publicationdetail/299/25"}},"2":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"8740A4B0BFC311EA92B67507D3F0A043","id":0,"label":"","temperature":"4","unit":10}},"3":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"8CEAAFA0BFC311EA92B67507D3F0A043","id":0,"label":"","temperature":"","unit":32}},"4":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"9122DB10BFC311EA92B67507D3F0A043","id":0,"label":"","temperature":"30","unit":10}},"5":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"96451860BFC311EA92B67507D3F0A043","id":0,"label":"","temperature":"37","unit":10}}}}

Thicker samples will require additional optimization.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"er82q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6if3","text":"We assume that the gels have been trimmed and cut to the appropriate size, and are currently stored in 1X PBS in PCR tubes or in microcentrifuge tubes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7nio0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bn3lt","text":"See note in Guidelines on volumes. For samples in microcentrifuge tubes, recipes can be scaled up appropriately to completely submerge the gel, typically 400-600 µL.
